- I have been vaccinated the three years I have worked in the hospital. It is very important. In my ward we have some patients who are seriously ill. It is important that I do not walk around and am a healthy carrier, ‚Äùsays Nygaard Byberg, who works in the neurological department.

14 joint vaccinations
On Tuesday, there was a joint vaccination for staff at the University Hospital. A total of 14 joint vaccinations are arranged. In addition, vaccines are put out in the wards.
- So far, 2278 doses have been set, says infection control consultant at SUS Jon Sundal.
- This is the third or fourth time I vaccinate, says Jan Erik Nilsen, who works as a consultant at the hospital. After the arm has been bitten, he must sit for 20 minutes.


Jan Erik Nilsen receives vaccine from nurse Kathrine Nygaard Byberg. Both work in the hospital. Several days to come, there will be vaccination of staff at SUS.üì∑ Kristian Jacobsen

- For me, it is important that, as a hospital employee, I do not infect patients, says Nilsen.
In recent years, the hospital has experienced an increasing number of employees thinking like Nilsen and Nygaard Byberg. Vaccination coverage has increased - first from 13 to 34 percent, and then last year a jump to a 55 percent coverage rate.
Target coverage of 75 percent


5100 doses of influenza vaccine have been ordered to the University Hospital in Stavanger. The goal is for at least 75 per cent of employees to vaccinate before the flu season of the year.üì∑ Kristian Jacobsen

The target is a coverage of 75 percent this year. The same goals also have the World Health Organization (WHO).
- We have been vaccinating employees for many years, but it has really taken off in recent years. More knowledge may be the explanation for that, says infection control chief Sundal.
He advises everyone in the risk groups to vaccinate - ie not just health workers with patient contact.
Nearly 1.6 million people in Norway belong to groups at increased risk of complications from the flu. Last year took a record number of flu vaccines.
Recent figures show that vaccination coverage in all target groups has almost doubled since 2015. In Rogaland, 42.9 percent of all over the age of 65 have been vaccinated.

Facts: Risk groups

The following people are at increased risk of serious illness and death from influenza disease, and are therefore recommended influenza vaccine:

All over 65 years
Residents in care homes and nursing homes
Pregnant after the 12th week (2nd and 3rd trimester). Pregnants in the first trimester with other additional risk should also be offered vaccine
Children and adults with:

diabetes mellitus, types 1 and 2
chronic lung disease (including asthma)
chronic cardiovascular disease, especially people with severe heart failure, low
minute volume or pulmonary hypertension
chronic liver failure
chronic kidney failure
chronic neurological disease or injury, especially people with impaired lung capacity
impaired immune system
very severe obesity (KMI over 40)
other serious and / or chronic illness where influenza represents a serious health risk, according to individual assessment by a physician


Great interest in the municipalities
In Sandnes municipality, they also experience great willingness among employees to vaccinate. Municipal physician Hans Petter Torvik, ordered 2500 more doses this year than last year, but has already run out.

- 600 doses arrived on Tuesday morning, but I'm afraid that's not enough either. But they have vaccines in stock at the Norwegian Institute of Public Health, and the delivery time is fantastic, says Torvik.
The municipality covers the cost of vaccination of health personnel. He feels that most employees in nursing homes, the home service and in the doctors' offices are vaccinated.

Facts: The influenza vaccine 2019/2020
Contains four types of influenza virus - two A strains and two B strains.
The effect of the flu vaccine varies from year to year, but averages around 60 percent. That is, about 6 out of 10 of those vaccinated are protected against influenza.
The effect depends on the characteristics of the virus, the vaccine and those being vaccinated. Some people get the flu despite the vaccine. For these, however, it appears that the vaccine may reduce the risk of serious illnesses.

- There are a few who do not want to, but in general there has been little noise around vaccination of health personnel in Sandnes, says Torvik.
He, too, urges residents of the risk groups to go to the doctor to vaccinate. The price for getting the vaccine is between 250 and 300 NOK.
In Stavanger, too, they are in full swing with vaccination, and Marit Anda, acting health director, has also had to order new doses.
- The doses go out to the general practitioner office, with a view to residents at risk groups, and are sent out to the health service, the home service, the nursing home, etc. All health personnel with patient contact are encouraged to vaccinate themselves, says Anda.
She says that the vaccination rate was particularly high last year at the emergency room offices at the emergency room, at 83 and 76 percent respectively.
Double the coverage in two years
According to the Institute of Public Health, vaccination coverage among health professionals has doubled in two years. Last year, 34 per cent of a cross-section of all health personnel in Norway was vaccinated, compared with 28 per cent in the 2017/18 season.
Estimates embrace all levels of service and types, and the Norwegian Institute of Public Health knows that some health enterprises have reached the target of 75 per cent coverage, while in some municipalities it may be somewhat lower than the 34 per cent estimate.
Coverage ratios also increase in the risk groups. Statistics from Statistics Norway show that self-reported vaccination coverage was 39 per cent last year - an increase of almost 50 per cent from the previous year when the coverage was 27 per cent. This includes those with chronic illness and anyone 65 years or older.
Fewer sick people last year
Last year's flu season is proof that increasing vaccination has an effect.
Last year, in excess of 100,000 received a flu diagnosis at the GP or emergency room, which is lower than average.
The influenza outbreak started around New Year and was over by the end of March. An estimated 4400 patients were hospitalized with influenza, against a record high 7600 patients the winter before.
